context: Thus, source longevity – an important attribute in estimating the long-term site management costs and the effectiveness of any remediation technology – also has not been estimated in previous studies.Sampling/analysis of groundwater in existing wells Sampling/analysis of groundwater from existing wells was conducted during 2001, and details are presented in the Supplemental Information (see Section S-1 and Table S-1). The sampling was divided into two phases. The first phase involved sampling in all available wells to: (i) re-map the TCE plume distribution; (ii) assess any movement since the last sampling event in February 1998; and (iii) identify wells to be re-sampled for detailed organic and inorganic constituent analysis, and for installation of VOC/oxygen probes. The second phase involved: (i) sampling groundwater from selected wells for detailed organic (TCE and its degradation byproducts cis- and trans-DCE) and inorganic (Cl−, SO4 −2, NO3 −, P, and S) constituent analysis to provide field evidence indicative of natural attenuation, and (ii) installation of on-line VOC/oxygen probes (Davis et al., 1997; Patterson et al., 1999, 2000; Patterson and Davis, 2008) to assess the depth profile of the TCE concentrations near the source and within the plume.Monitoring using on-line VOC and oxygen probes On-line VOC and oxygen probes (Davis et al., 1997; Patterson et al., 1999, 2000; Patterson and Davis, 2008) were installed in two groups at the site, during 20–22 March 2001. One group of six probes was installed ∼2 m up-gradient of the well MW205 (see Fig. 1) located in the source zone. These probes allowed monitoring at depths of 11.5, 13.9, 16.4, 18.8 and 21.3 m bgs. The other group of six probes was installed ∼2 m up-gradient of the well MW218 (located about 175 m down-gradient of the source zone, see Fig. 1), allowing monitoring at depths of 11.5, 13.9, 16.4, 18.8, 21.3 and 23.7 m bgs.

llm_generation.summary: In this context, 1,1,2-trichloroethene (TCE) is analyzed in relation to its natural attenuation in groundwater. The study involves monitoring TCE concentrations and its degradation products to assess the effectiveness of remediation technologies. While TCE is a focus of the analysis, the term 'attenuation' refers to the process of reducing its concentration over time, indicating a relationship between TCE and its natural degradation mechanisms. However, the specifics of how attenuation occurs in relation to TCE are not deeply explored in the provided context.
llm_generation.reason: The score of 3 reflects a moderate relevance, as TCE is directly linked to the concept of attenuation in the context of groundwater monitoring and remediation. However, the details of their interaction are not extensively discussed, limiting the strength of their relationship.
